prompt.body:
You have just visited your aunt's new house. You write an email to a friend.
Je bent in het nieuwe huis van je tante geweest. Je stuurt een vriend(in) een e-mail.

  • Begroet je vriend(in).
  • Vraag hoe het met je vriend(in) gaat en vertel hoe het met jou gaat.
  • Zeg dat je gaat vertellen over het nieuwe huis van je tante.
  • Vertel waar het huis bij in de buurt is.
  • Vertel welke kleur de woonkamer is.
  • Noem twee dingen die je tante in de woonkamer heeft.
  • Vertel nog iets over het huis. Bedenk dit zelf.
  • Vertel wat je het leukst vindt aan het nieuwe huis.
  • Sluit netjes af.

values.value:
2 p per goed antwoord

Voorbeeld:

Dear Aisha,

[1] How are you? I am fine.

I am going to tell you about my aunt’s new house.

[2] It is is near the beach / the city centre / school / the stores / public transportation.

[3] The main colour in the living room is white / black / blue / red / pink / yellow / orange / green / purple.

[4] My aunt has got a computer / a TV / a game console / a watch / jewellery / sunglasses / a phone and a computer / a TV / a game console / a watch / jewellery / sunglasses / a phone in her living room.

[5] The most important thing in the house is the kitchen. / What I like about the house is that it’s big.

[6] What I like most about her new house is the cinema / the elevator / the view / the attic / the basement / the yard / the bathroom / the dining room.

 

Bye for now,

[your name]

Blue whale

The blue whale is the largest animal to have ever lived on Earth. Blue whales are even larger than the largest dinosaur! The biggest blue whales can become 100 feet long, which is longer than three school buses put together.

Even though blue whales are huge, they eat very small creatures: krill. Krill are tiny shrimp-like animals. The whale simply opens its mouth, fills it with krill and salt water, and filters the water out of its mouth. The blue whale can eat over 8,000 pounds of krill in a single day!

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the question.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vraag.

Todd: Hi, what's your name?

Nanju: My name is Nanju.

Todd: That's a nice name. Where are you from, Nanju?

Nanju: I live in Japan.

Todd: But you're not from Japan originally, are you?

Nanju: No, originally I'm from Madras. That's in India. Most of my family still lives there.

Todd: Tell me about your family.

Nanju: My parents died when I was young, so I was raised by my aunt and uncle. That means we have a large family - I have two brothers and a sister, and my aunt and uncle have five children of their own.

Todd: You said most of your family still lives in India. But not all of them?

Nanju: No, my oldest brother lives in the USA and one of my cousins lives in the UK. She's studying History there.

Todd: So how long have you been in Japan?

Nanju: I've been here for four months now, working.

Todd: What do you do?

Nanju: I'm a software engineer. Nothing special, I know, but I enjoy it.

Todd: Oh, you're a software engineer! So you can help me with my computer then?

Nanju: No, sorry! I don't know anything about fixing computers, I just know how to program!

1. Where was Nanju born?

content.body: 1. In India (in Madras, India)

prompt.body:
You are going to write an email to your pen pal.
Je gaat een mailtje schrijven aan je penvriend(in).

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

In Great Britain you have different types of shops and stores:

Department Stores
These are large retail stores. They sell a variety of goods and services (e.g. Marks & Spencer, Allders Department Store, Woolworths)

Shopping centre / Mall
Shopping centres have a variety of shops under one roof. They will have an eating area with fast foods and sit down menus, parking area and often a cinema.

Corner shop
A corner shop is a small shop near houses. It has a limited variety of food but often has long opening hours.

Supermarkets
Supermarkets are large self-service shops selling mainly food. Large supermarkets also sell household goods.

Charity shops
Charity shops sell goods (clothes, book and small household items) that have been donated.
The items are usually very cheap and of good quality.

Chain stores
Chain stores are a number of retail stores under the same ownership selling the same goods.

  1. Where can you sit down and eat or drink something?
  2. Where can you go for second-hand clothes?
  3. Where can you go to buy groceries?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the question.

A very special wedding dress

Shopping for a wedding dress can be both challenging and time-consuming, and with wedding season upon us, we thought we'd show you a more creative alternative.

Welcome to the 12th annual toilet paper wedding dress contest. Yes, that's dresses made out of, you guessed it, toilet paper. The annual competition offers a more creative twist to bridal attire and the competitors were flushed with excitement as they made it down to the final 10 out of 1,500 hopefuls aiming for the ten-thousand dollar prize.

The designers were only allowed to use toilet paper, glue, tape, needles and thread to create their masterpieces. The winning dress, dubbed 'Winter Last' was inspired by the creator's first snowstorm experience.

'I was like, what happens when you have a winter wedding? Because that can be really beautiful. What would you wear? So I definitely developed a snow queen kind of attire.'

The prize-winning creation isn't for sale, but it will be on display at one of Ripley's Believe It or Not global locations. So if you're feeling creative, this is one you may want to try at home.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

School Uniform
Most schools in England require children to wear a school uniform.

Boys

  • Long grey or black trousers (shorts may be worn in summer);
  • White shirt;
  • School tie (optional in most primary schools);
  • Jumper or sweater with the school logo. Schools choose their own colour;
  • Black shoes.​

Girls
As above. Girls may wear skirts.
During the summer term, girls often wear summer school dresses.

Why wear a uniform?

  • When we go on a school trip, we all look the same and so can't get lost.
  • Kids don't have to worry about what to wear each day.
  • Everyone is equal.
  • Parents don't have to shop for expensive and varied wardrobes for their children to keep up with or show off to other children.
  • Wearing a uniform instills a sense of pride and discipline in students.​

Why not to wear a uniform?
Uniforms deny students their right to a personal identity and self-expression.

  1. Can girls wear trousers if they want? Explain your answer.
  2. What is the advantage of uniforms for parents? Explain it in your own words.
  3. Do you think school uniforms are a good idea? Explain your answer using two arguments from the text.

2 They don’t have to spend so much time and money on buying trendy clothes. (2 punten)

3 I think it’s a great idea, because I never know what to wear and I can;t afford expensive clothes. / I  think it’s a bad idea, because I want to decide for myself what to wear. I don;t want to look like everyone else. (4 punten)

content.body: d They write news stories. That could mean going to school events and coming back with a story, or maybe going to get information from several people and piecing it together to make a story that explains things clearly to readers.

f Someone needs to decide what the paper should look like. They can use artwork and design skills to get the pages looking really interesting. They will probably be pretty good with graphics packages on the computer.
a You could get someone good at art to do a cartoon for each issue of the paper. They could even do a comic strip.
e They are the boss of the paper - they decide what sort of stories it should cover and let the staff know who is doing what.

c Photos are great for attracting readers to your stories. The quality can be a bit dodgy if you are photocopying your paper, so it's good to have someone who knows what they are doing with a digital camera.

You probably also need to lighten the pictures with some picture edit software before you paste them into your DTP package.
b A big sports fan who would go along to school matches and write a report. They need to know the rules and scoring systems. Someone into lots of different sports would be ideal.

3 Reporters

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

School students do not shower after sports class

A report has found out that more than half of high school boys and two-thirds of girls never shower after a physical education class.

Researchers suggest that students don't want to sweat and take a shower, so they are less active in sports classes.

The BBC says the study did not look at the exact reasons why the students did not shower after PE. Undressing in front of classmates may be too much for some children.

Pamela Naylor, spokeswoman for a health organisation in England, said many children had concerns about their body image and that schools needed to address this.

She said: "Schools, workplaces and local authorities all have a role to play in shifting attitudes so that physical activity, and what comes with it, like sweating and the need for showering, is encouraged and accommodated."

Answer the questions in English and in your own words. Be careful: not all the questions are in the correct order.

  1. What is the problem?
  2. What is the most likely reason for this problem?
  3. What effect does this have on students' behaviour in P.E.?
  4. What should be done about the problem?

2 They don’t want to take their clothes off in front of other classmates.
3 Students are less active because they don’t want to get sweaty.

4 Schools, workplaces and local authorities need to convince people that exercise is necessary, even if it means getting sweaty and having to take a shower.

Catching a wave and catching a break

Twelve surfers advance to the semi-finals after successfully taking on the giant waves of the Big Wave Tour Puerto Escondido Challenge in Mexico.

Competing against each other and nature, the surfers grappled with the huge waves, and it was Americans Will Skudin, Makuakai Rothman, Greg Long, and Australian Jamie Mitchell who topped the scoresheets of the six-man heats. Mitchell recorded the highest single wave score of the day with a perfect 10 after surviving a barrel ride through one of the mighty waves.

The Puerto Escondido Challenge is the first event of the World's Surf League Big Wave Tour, which consists of 6 events that will take place through February of next year. And riding those surfs is no mean feat - waves must reach at least 20 feet (6 metres) in height for an event to take place. That's got to take some guts.

Imagine chocolate that keeps you younger-looking!

It sounds too good to be true, but scientists working with Cambridge University have invented an anti-ageing chocolate. It keeps away wrinkles and helps the skin look younger.

The chocolate's name is 'Esthechoc': a combination of the words 'esthetic' (meaning all things beautiful) and 'chocolate'. It is also called Cambridge Beauty Chocolate. The lab hopes young, rich business executives will buy it.

The chocolate contains a special chemical that gives flamingos their pink colour. Scientists say the chemical can make the skin of a 50-to-60-year-old person look like that of a 20-to-30-year-old.

Other scientists say more research is needed to verify whether or not Esthechoc works.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Best Holiday
Three students answer the question: What is your country's best holiday?

Phoebe from China
I think the spring festival is the best holiday in China.
It is the main festival in China and it is also called Chinese new year. On this day, we celebrate the beginning of the new year according to the lunar calendar. During the spring festival, families always get together and the children get their red pack, which is an envelope with money put in. We also eat little pastries with custard of sweet bean past inside called mooncakes. Everybody likes that holiday.

Kat from Germany
In my home country, Germany, I think the best holiday is Christmas. In my opinion, the Christmas season is amazing. The best thing about Christmas are probably the seasonal markets where you can buy all kinds of delicious food.

Christmas time normally comes with a lot of snow and an amazing atmosphere. My mom always makes these fabulous cookies, and we have lots of friends and family over to our house, so it's a wonderful time.

Antoinette from United States
I'm from the U.S., so I would say the best holiday would be Thanksgiving, a federal holiday which we celebrate each year on the fourth Thursday of November.

Although there are some aspects of that holiday that I don't like, like the overeating, I do like the fact that families get together. My parents always make an incredible meal with turkey, several veggie dishes and mashed and baked potatoes. At the dinner table, we talk about what we're thankful for that year.

  1. What is the spring festival also called?
  2. What do kids get during the spring festival?
  3. What does Kat like best during the Christmas season?
  4. What doesn't Antoinette like about Thanksgiving?
  5. When is thanksgiving celebrated?
  6. What do families talk about during Thanksgiving? And where do they talk about it?

Rick: "Hi! It's a nice day, isn't it."
Alexis: "Yes. It is a beautiful day."

Rick: "Do you live around here or are you visiting?"
Alexis: "I am on vacation from Korea."

Rick: "That's cool. Are you having a good time?"
Alexis: "Yes. There are many things to see, and I'm taking a lot of pictures. Do you live in this city?"

Rick: "Yeah. I'm just here with my parents. They wanted to come to the park today."
Alexis: "What's a good place to visit in this city?"

Rick: "Where have you been so far?"
Alexis: "This was my first stop. I am going to visit the Natural History Museum with a friend tomorrow."

Rick: "I recommend going to the water front downtown. They have a ferry you can ride, some good restaurants, and a good beach for a walk."
Alexis: "How do I get there from here?"

Rick: "You see Jackson street over there? Go straight for 10 blocks. When you see 5th Avenue, turn left. Follow the street for about 3 miles and you should see it."
Alexis: "Thanks. I'll go check it out. It was nice talking to you."

Rick: "It was nice meeting you. Have a good time."

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Home is where the heart is.

"Home is where the heart is" is a popular saying. I really like this proverb because I believe it is so true. When you are growing up, home is where your family lives. But when you move away, because you go to college or because you're simply too old to live at your parents anymore, this changes. I left home when I was 18 and slowly my childhood home was no longer. All my stuff was moved to my new home and my old bedroom became a home gym. Now, it's has complete transformed into my parents' house and is no longer my home.

Since I've left my parent's home, I have moved around a lot. I only spent a year or so in most places I lived in and, somehow, they never really felt like home.
In my opinion, a home is somewhere you feel totally relaxed and where you want to return to every night. I am moving to a new flat next month and I really hope that place will feel like home. I painted the walls in my new living room my favourite colour and I invested in some new furniture that I really love. So I think that's a step in the right direction.

The expression "Home Sweet Home" is also true. You have to have nice feelings about the place where you live to call it home. Whenever you come home from a trip you should feel glad to be there again and when you've been away from home for a long time you should long for it. That's how you know your house is also your home.
  1. What does the term childhood home mean?
  2. Which statement is true?
    A. The writer lived in a lot of different homes.
    B. The writer lived in the same home his whole life.
  3. What is 'home' according to the writer?
  4. What is the writer going to do next month?
  5. What does the expression "home sweet home" mean according to the writer?

  6. Which three two other terms for 'a saying' are used in the text?

5 That you have nice feelings about the place where you live.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Facebook

Facebook is a social networking service and website started by Mark Zuckerberg in February of 2004 when he was still a student. Starting the website wasn't easy as it was shut down by Harvard University multiple times. The website was originally only accessible for students of Harvard University. In the following years, students from other university were able to use the website. In 2006 the website became available for the public. From that moment onward, the website started to grow. People from all over the world joined the platform and started to connect with each other.

After registering to use the site, users may create a personal profile, add other users as friends, exchange messages, post status updates and photos, and receive notifications when others update their profiles.

Nowadays, Facebook has millions of users. The company has expanded to other platforms as well. Facebook now owns other social media websites, like Instagram and WhatsApp.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Why British tabloids are so extreme

Sensation sells. The British tabloid papers know this all too well. The British press has accumulated so much power they can do whatever they want. Exaggerating the number of deaths in the 17th century English civil war, making up fake news reports about famous serial killer Jack the ripper and stalking Prince Harry and Megan to the extent that they didn't feel safe anymore; they've done it all. Somehow, tabloid papers manage to combine politics, sports and gossip so seamlessly together that readers don't even question the lies they are told and this is a problem.

You might wonder: how are they able to do this? Is it even allowed to print lies about other people's lives. The answer is money. These papers are so wealthy they can afford to bribe people to either keep their mouths shut or give them false information and hire the best lawyers whenever they get sued.

  1. What sells papers according to the text?
  2. What are British tabloids known for?
  3. What don't readers realise?
  4. Why are British tabloids able to do whatever they want?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the question.

First time in love

Anne: Kate, I have something wonderful to tell you. I'm in love!
Kate: Wow Anne! That's so exciting indeed. Who's the lucky guy?
Anne: His name is Paul and I met him at the tennis club. I had seen him play before and thought he was handsome. But a few weeks ago we started talking and the rest is history.
Kate: Is this your first time being in love?
Anne: Yes, how old were you when you fell in love with your first boyfriend?
Kate: I fell in love for the first time when I was 14. He was a few years older and I thought he was so cool.
Anne: OK, so how did you meet him?
Kate: We met through mutual friends. My friend Desiree introduced me to him. She thought we would hit it off, and we did.
Anne: Where did you go on your first date?
Kate: We went to the cinema. We shared some popcorn and he held my hand during the movie. I thought it was very romantic.
Anne: So, were your parents cool with you having a boyfriend?
Kate: Yes, they really liked him. He often joined us for dinner, so they got to know him very well.
Anne: Are you still in love with him?
Kate: No, unfortunately we broke up a few months ago.


1. Where did Anne meet the boy she's in love with?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Friends fight

Last night, I got into a huge fight with my best friend Thom. We were at a party at another friend's house. He wanted to leave, but I didn't because my crush was there too. This was my one chance to talk to her. She was finally paying attention to me when my friend started to pull me towards the door. "Come on Kevin! I want to leave." He said over and over again. I'm not proud of what happened next: I snapped. At first, I just raised my voice, but then he started to shout. We called each other names and said horrible things to each other that we didn't mean. At one point I even pushed him. I can't believe I did that. I really regret it. Luckily, one of our other friends came between us and stopped the fight. Thom left and I felt horrible. I didn't want to fight, I just wanted to stay at the party and impress my crush.

This morning, I called Thom to apologize. He was hurt by all the things I had said in the heat of the moment, but he accepted my apology. I also told him that I should have gone home with him. It turns out that Thom wanted to leave because his ex was at the party with her new boyfriend. He didn't tell me because he was ashamed that he still had feelings for her. So, we came up with a plan. In the future, we will always tell each other the truth, and we will always listen to each other's point of view without getting mad.


1. Why didn't Kevin (the writer) want to go home?

2. Who started the fight?

3. What happened during the fight?

4. Why did Thom want to go home?

5. What are Kevin and Thom going to do in the future to prevent fights from happening?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Doctor's office

I was feeling a little ill the other day. I felt nauseous and I had a splitting headache. So, the next day, I decided to visit my doctor before things got worse. I called the doctor's office in the morning, and I made an appointment for 9:30 a.m.

When I arrived at the surgery, the nurse gave me some forms: I had to fill out some insurance paperwork and a form describing my current medical condition, along with the symptoms I was feeling.
After a few minutes, the nurse called my name and took me back to one of their examination rooms. It was a large room with a desk and chairs, a bed to examine people on and bookshelves full of medical books.
The nurse checked my vital signs including my temperature and blood pressure and then I was asked to wait until the doctor came in.
The GP arrived shortly after that. He asked me a few questions and examined my stomach. After the examination, he asked me a few more questions. The doctor's diagnosis was that I had a bacterial infection.
She wrote me a prescription for some medication, which I was supposed to take two times a day.
After the appointment, I went to the pharmacy to pick up the medicine. Luckily the pharmacy is located next to the surgery, so I didn't have to walk far. Then I went home with my medicine and went to bed, because I still felt sick. I hope I will feel better tomorrow.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Healthy habits

Developing healthy habits such as eating healthy and exercising helps protect you from physical and mental problems. You'll feel and function better and feel healthier. Here are some examples of healthy habits.

1. Eat breakfast every day
Breakfast is the "most important meal of the day." You need it to replenish the supply of glucose your body lost overnight. A healthy morning meal provides the nutrients needed for your brain and body to function well.

2. Drink enough water
Drinking plenty of water helps remove toxins from your body and replaces fluids lost through sweat and urine. Water also improves the movement of nutrients and oxygen to your cells. Drink 8 glasses of water a day, as recommended by doctors, to stay hydrated and keep your body functioning well.

3. Keep yourself active
You don't have to go to the gym to exercise. Keeping your body moving is considered exercise. Physical movement increases blood circulation, burns calories, and helps maintain heart health. Take the stairs up instead of the elevator or get up and move around your house or workplace every 30 minutes.

20. Put away electronics ahead of bedtime
You have to set boundaries with your electronic devices if you want to have the best sleep. Blue light from these devices interferes with the body's release of melatonin, a hormone that makes you feel drowsy. End screen time with your TV, phone, tablet, or laptop about 2-3 hours before bedtime. Set an alarm to remind you to turn off electronics.

[adapted from https://www.developgoodhabits.com/healthy-habits/]

1. Why are healthy habits good for you according to the text?

Read the text about Labor Day and answer the questions.

In the 1800s, men and women worked 12 to 16 hours a day, 7 days a week.

They made very little money, had no benefits, did not get any money when they were sick and did not get any vacations. Children worked too.

Obviously, the workers were not happy and wanted a better life, but they were afraid to ask for better pay because they did not want to lose their jobs.

Then they realized that if they joined their forces, they would have more power.

Finally, workers united and set up labor unions to be able to ask for better pay and conditions.

In 1869 the first labor union was set up. The unions helped workers improve their lives.

Peter McGuire, a man who used to work in a factory as a child, became president of a labor union and fought for holiday for workers.

On 5 September 1882, for the first time, there was a big parade in New York City for all the workers in the United States.

And in 1894 McGuire's dream came true and Labor Day became a national holiday.
Now Labor Day is always the first Monday in September.

Most people do not go to work on this day and enjoy themselves by having barbecues, picnics or watching the Labor Day parades.


Which of the following sentences of this text are correct?

a

before labor unions existed, workers had vacations.
before labor unions existed, workers had no vacations.

b

labor unions help workers improve their lives.
labor unions do not help workers.


Which of the two events have previously occurred?

c

There is a big parade in New York City for all the workers.
Peter McGuire want a holiday for workers.

d

Workers wanted to improve their lives.
Workers decided to work together.

items.value: before labor unions existed, workers had vacations.
before labor unions existed, workers had no vacations.
labor unions help workers improve their lives.
labor unions do not help workers.
There is a big parade in New York City for all the workers.
Peter McGuire want a holiday for workers.
Workers wanted to improve their lives.

prompt.body:
Read the text below and answer the questions.

10-year-old girl born in China wants to run for U.S. President

Alena Mulhern, a 10-year-old girl adopted from China who now lives in Kingston, Massachusetts, wants U.S. laws to change so that she can run for the office of President of the United States. Right now, only those who are born in the United States can run for this office.

Alena spoke to members of the Massachusetts State House, and shared her feeling that everyone should have a chance to be U.S. President. She tried to convince House members to ask the U.S. Congress to change the U.S. Constitution, making it possible for children adopted from other countries to be able to run for office. Alena thinks the law is very old, and that all good people should be allowed the chance to become U.S. President.

Having moved to the U.S. at just 10 months old, Alena says she is just as American as others born in the United States. Alena has set a goal to change U.S. law, and will not let anyone tell her that being President is something she can't do.

Even though blue whales are huge, they eat very small creatures: krill. Krill are tiny shrimp-like animals. The whale simply opens its mouth, fills it with krill and salt water, and filters the water out of its mouth. The blue whale can eat over 8,000 pounds of krill in a single day!

prompt.body:
You are going to read a story about Sign language (= gebarentaal).
After reading the story, answer the question below.

Sign language

Deaf people can't hear, so wherever there are communities of deaf people, sign languages develop so people can communicate with each other.

They are equally as complex and rich as any other language and they can be used to discuss any topic from simple ideas to abstract concepts.

There are hundreds of sign languages in use throughout the world.

Sign languages have often evolved around schools for the deaf.

Sign languages do not have a written form.

Sign language is gradually becoming more visible in the wider community.

Some television programmes provide a sign language interpreter and there is new television technology emerging which allows a viewer to turn on a signer, in the same way they can turn on subtitles for a foreign movie.


Deaf means that someone:

can't see
can't speak

prompt.body:
Read the telephone conversation below and answer the question.

A: "Hello? This is Steve."
B: "Hi Steve, this is Mary from ABC Company. I'm returning your call."

A: "Hi Mary. How are you doing?"
B: "I'm doing great thanks."

A: "Thanks for returning my call. I couldn't figure out why the ending balance on fiscal year 2003 didn't match the beginning balance on 2004."
B: "When I checked, it was matching. How much is the difference?"

A: "The amount is exactly $42,000."
B: "Oh. I know what the problem is. We opened another bank account at the end of fiscal year 2003. I might not have included the new bank statements when I sent over the information."

A: "That makes sense. I'm just glad it wasn't out of my miscalculation. Can you send over the statements? I should be done by end of day since everything looks good."
B: "Sure. I'll fax them to you immediately. Is 555-123-4567 the number I should fax it to?"

A: "Yes. That is the correct number."
B: "I'll do it right now."

A: "Thank you for your help."
B: "I should have sent them over to you the first time. I apologize for that."

A: "No problem."
B: "Thank you."

A: "Thank you. Bye."

fiscal year - begrotingsjaar

prompt.body:
You are going to read a story about Types of shops and stores.
After reading the story, answer the questions.

In Great Britain you have different types of shops and stores:

Department Stores
These are large retail stores. They sell a variety of goods and services (e.g. Marks & Spencer, Allders Department Store, Woolworths)

Shopping centre / Mall
Shopping centres have a variety of shops under one roof. They will have an eating area with fast foods and sit down menus, parking area and often a cinema.

Corner shop
A corner shop is a small shop near houses. It has a limited variety of food but often has long opening hours.

Supermarkets
Supermarkets are large self-service shops selling mainly food. Large supermarkets also sell household goods.

Charity shops
Charity shops sell goods (clothes, book and small household items) that have been donated.
The items are usually very cheap and of good quality

Off-Licences
Off-Licence shops sell alcoholic beverages.

Chain stores
Chain stores are a number of retail stores under the same ownership selling the same goods.

  1. Can you park your car in a Shopping Centre?
  2. In what kind of shop will you buy a second-hand dress?

  3. Mention three articles you can buy in a supermarket.

values.value:
1. Yes
  2. Charity shop
  3. Milk, sugar, bread, soap, drinks, eggs, vegetables

content.body:
1. Yes
  2. Charity shop
  3. Milk, sugar, bread, soap, drinks, eggs, vegetables

Below you find some information on Shopping streets.

Shopping streets

The main shopping street in many towns is called the High Street.
You should head for if you want to go shopping.
A few small shops are owned by local people.
Most are owned by national 'chains' of stores (= winkelketens).
This makes many town centres look the same.
Some towns also have street markets where fresh food and cheap goods can be bought. Away from the town centre, small 'corner' shops provide groceries to local customers.

Very special wedding dress

Shopping for a wedding dress can be both challenging and time-consuming, and with wedding season upon us, we thought we'd show you a more creative alternative.

Welcome to the 12th annual toilet paper wedding dress contest. Yes, that's dresses made out of, you guessed it, toilet paper. The annual competition offers a more creative twist to bridal attire and the competitors were flushed with excitement as they made it down to the final 10 out of 1,500 hopefuls.

The designers were only allowed to use toilet paper, glue, tape, needles and thread to create their masterpieces. The winning dress dubbed "Winter Last" was inspired by the creator's first snowstorm experience.

prompt.body:
You are going to read a story about School uniforms. After reading the story, answer the question below.

School Uniform
Most schools in England require children to wear a school uniform.

Boys

  • Long grey or black trousers (shorts may be worn in the Summer)
  • White shirt
  • School tie (optional in most primary schools)
  • Jumper or sweater with the school logo on. The colour is the choice of the schools.
  • Black shoes.​

Girls
As above. Girls may wear skirts.
During the summer term girls often wear summer school dresses.

Why wear a uniform?

  • When we go on a school trip we all look the same and so can't get lost.
  • Stops kids worrying about what to wear each day.
  • Everyone is equal.
  • Parents don't have to shop for expensive and varied wardrobes for their children to keep up with or show-off to other children.
  • Wearing a uniform instills a sense of pride and discipline in students.​

Why not to wear a uniform?
Uniforms deny students their right to personal identity and self-expression.


What do girls often wear during the summer?

content.body: dresses
trousers
hats

prompt.body:
School newspapers
Having a newspaper or magazine can also make your school a better place.
By letting people know what's going on, you make it easier to organise clubs and events.
Papers also help people talk about the things that they are unhappy with and that can lead to changes in the way a school works. You can also learn about the different jobs involved and work out which one you might be interested in. To realize a school newspaper you need volunteers (= vrijwilligers).

What jobs are there to make a newspaper?

content.body: Someone needs to decide how the paper should look. They can use artwork and design skills to get the pages looking really interesting. They will probably be pretty good with graphics packages on the computer.

They write news stories. That could mean going to school events and coming back with a story, or maybe going to get information from several people and piecing it together to make a story that explains things clearly to readers.
You could get someone good at art to do a cartoon for each issue of the paper. They could even do a comic strip

Photos are great for attracting readers to your stories. The quality can be a bit dodgy if you are photocopying your paper, so it's good to have someone who knows what they are doing with a digital camera.

You probably also need to lighten the pictures some picture edit software before you paste them into your DTP package.
He/she is the boss of the paper - they decide what sort of stories it should cover and let the staff know who is doing what.
A big sports fan who would go along to school matches and write you a report. They need to know the rules and scoring systems. Someone into lots of different sports would be ideal.
Editor
Cartoonist
Reporters
Designer
Photographer
Sports writer

prompt.body:
You are going to read a story about Showering after sports class.
After reading the story, answer the questions below.

School students do not shower after sports class

A report has found out that more than half of high school boys and two-thirds of girls never shower after a physical education class.

Researchers suggest that students don't want to sweat and take a shower, so they are less active in sports classes.

The BBC says the study did not look at the exact reasons why the students did not shower after PE. Undressing in front of classmates may be too much for some children.

Pamela Naylor, spokeswoman for a health organisation in England, said many children had concerns about their body image and that schools needed to address this.

She said: "Schools, workplaces and local authorities all have a role to play in shifting attitudes so that physical activity, and what comes with it, like sweating and the need for showering, is encouraged and accommodated."

  1. Are school boys showering more often than school girls?
  2. What could be the reason that students are less active in sports classes?

  3. Do the students find it difficult to undress before the sports class?

values.value:
1. No
  2. They don’t want to sweat and take a shower.
  3. Yes, they don’t like to undress in front of class mates.

content.body:
1. No
  2. They don't want to sweat and take a shower.
  3. Yes, they don't like to undress in front of class mates.

prompt.body:
Read the text below and answer the questions:

Big Wave Tour in Mexico

Catching a wave and catching a break. Twelve surfers advance to the semi-finals after successfully taking on the giant waves of the Big Wave Tour Puerto Escondido Challenge in Mexico.

Competing against each other and nature, the surfers grappled with the huge waves and it was Americans Will Skudin, Makuakai Rothman, Greg Long, and Australian Jamie Mitchell who topped the score sheets of the six-man heats. Mitchell recorded the highest single wave score of the day with a perfect 10 after surviving a barrel ride through one of the mighty waves.

The Puerto Escondido Challenge is the first event of the World's Surf League Big Wave Tour, which consists of 6 events that will take place through February of next year. And riding those surfs is no mean feat - waves must reach at least 20 feet (6 metres) in height for an event to take place. That's got to take some guts.

prompt.body:
Read the text below and answer the question:

PUBS

The word pub is short for public house.

There are over 60,000 pubs in the UK (53,000 in England and Wales, 5,200 in Scotland and 1,600 in Northern Ireland). One of the oldest pubs, Fighting Cocks in St. Albans, Herts, is located in a building that dates back to the eleventh century.

Pubs are popular social meeting places
Pubs are an important part of British life. People talk, eat, drink, meet their friends and relax there. Pubs often have two bars, one usually quieter than the other.

Many pubs have a garden where people can sit in the summer.

Children can go in pub gardens with their parents.

Groups of friends normally buy 'rounds' of drinks, where the person whose turn it is will buy drinks for all the members of the group.

If you spill (= morsen) a stranger's drink by accident, it is good manners to offer to buy another drink.

Pubs sell soft drinks as well as alcohol
Although most people think pubs are places where people drink alcohol, pubs in fact sell soft drinks (non alcoholic) too.

British people drink an average of 99.4 litres of beer every year.

More than 80% of this beer is drunk in pubs and clubs.


Can you mention - at least - four beer brands?
(Dutch, English or international)

Children's bad teeth

The reason for the children's rotten teeth is unhealthy food. The children are eating too much processed food and drinking fizzy drinks with a lot of sugar in them.

prompt.body:
Read the text below and answer the question.

April Fool's Day

April Fool's Day started in the sixteenth century in Europe. Before that time, New Year's Day was celebrated on April 1st. Then a new calendar was introduced called the Gregorian calendar. January 1st became the first day of the year, but many people did not know about it. So those who continued to celebrate New Year's Day on April 1st were teased. They were called fools.

Nowadays we play jokes on people on April 1st. For example, someone might put salt in the sugar container so another person could "accidentally" put it in their coffee. Or someone might change the time on another person's alarm clock so that person would unknowingly wake up earlier or later than planned. Or maybe a person would tell a lie to make someone else shocked.

After we play the trick, we say "April Fool." Then the poor person realizes he was fooled. It is generally done in the spirit of fun and doesn't cause any real harm to anyone. Do you have any great jokes to play on anyone today? Try it out. Just don't forget to say "April Fool" when the other person begins looking a little confused.

Word list:
calendar - kalender
teased - geplaagd
accidentally - per ongeluk
unknowingly - onwetend/onbewust
generally - over het algemeen
confused - verward

  1. What was celebrated on April 1st before the Gregorian calendar was introduced?
  2. Why were people who celebrated New Year's Day on April 1st called fools.
  3. What should you say when the person you fooled begins looking a little confused?

values.value:
1. New Year’s Day
  2. Because they didn’t know that because of the new calendar, New Year’s Day wasn’t celebrated on April 1st anymore.
  3. April Fool!

content.body:
1. New Year's Day
  2. Because they didn't know that because of the new calendar, New Year's Day wasn't celebrated on April 1st anymore.
  3. April Fool!

prompt.body:
You are going to read a story about Street Numbering.
After reading the text, answer the question below.

Street numbering was introduced by act of Parliament in 1765.
Every house in a town and city has a number followed by the name of the road it is in e.g. 26 Avebury Avenue.
The first house in the road is number one and the last house is the number of buildings in the street.
The number readily identifies the location of a property in a road and so makes it easier for the emergency services to find houses quickly.
Odd (= oneven) numbers are usually assigned to the left side of the street and even numbers to the right, as they head out of town.

  1. When was the street numbering introduced?
  2. Which number has the first house of the street?
  3. On which side of the street you will find houses with odd numbers?

values.value:

prompt.body:
During the summer holidays you and your family like to homeswap (= woningruil) with another family.
You are looking for a nice apartment, near the beach in the South.
You can offer a large, sunny 3-bedroom apartment in Central London.

Which features (= voorzieningen) do you prefer?
Name at least 5 things you wish to find in or around the apartment.

For example: Luxery bathroom

  1. ​a fireplace
  2. a computer
  3. a wide view
  4. shopping centre nearby
  5. free parking
  6. modern kitchen

prompt.body:
Homestay or University Dormitories
When many international students move overseas to study English, they often have to decide whether to live on campus in a dormitory (= slaapzaal), or stay with a host family.

However, each comes with its benefits and challenges.
Some international students prefer to live with a homestay family when they study in a foreign country.

There are a number of companies that could help students find homestay opportunities.
When doing homestay, get involved with the host family as much as possible.
Volunteer to help around the house. Be a part of the family.

Can you think of three advantages and three disadvantages of a homestaying situation?

values.value:
Advantages:

  1. More silence, better for concentration to study.
  2. You will be taken care of.
  3. More family coziness.​

Disadvantages:

  1. Less contact with study mates.
  2. Further away from school.
  3. You have to keep the rules of the house.
